class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. View our <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/researcher/author/submit-your-paper\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing with Elsevier: step-by-step</span></span></a> page to learn more about the publishing process. object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2024.08.054</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0021979724018423&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="ab010"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010">The off-stoichiometric compound Na<sub>3.12</sub>Fe<sub>2.44</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>2</sub> (NFPO) is a highly promising, cost-effective, and structurally robust cathode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, the slowing Na-ion migration kinetics and poor interface stability have seriously limited its rate capability and air stability. In this work, we successfully synthesis a sodium titanium pyrophosphate (NaTiP<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> donated as NTPO) coating NFPO (denoted as NFPO-NTPO) cathode material via a liquid phase coating method for SIBs. After optimizing NTPO content, at 0.1C, NFPO-NTPO-4&nbsp;% cathode achieves a reversible specific capacity of 108.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. Remarkably, it maintains 88.39&nbsp;% capacity at 10C comparing to 0.1C and stabilizes over 3000 cycles with 92.66&nbsp;% retention rate. Moreover, it retains 88.89&nbsp;% capacity after 5000 cycles at 20C, even after 28&nbsp;days of air exposure. The NFPO-Ti cathode, alongside the complete battery system, exhibits remarkable electrochemical performance across a broad temperature range spanning from −40 to 60 ℃.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-ga1.jpg" height="185" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (103KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (103KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724020782"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724020149"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion Batteries</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Sodium Iron Pyrophosphate</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Sodium Titanium Pyrophosphate</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Interface Modification</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have great potential for large-scale energy storage due to their low cost and abundant resources. However, the larger ionic radius of sodium ions (Na<sup>+</sup>: 1.02&nbsp;Å) compared to lithium ions (Li<sup>+</sup>: 0.76&nbsp;Å) significantly limits their rate capabilities and structural stability.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>. Therefore, the work to develop high structural stability, long lifespan, and high rate capability electrode materials has become the key to achieve the practical application of SIBs. Thus far, carbon-based materials have emerged as the predominant choice for anodes in SIBs, due to great cycle stability and rate capability<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>. Cathode materials exhibiting promising prospects for application in SIBs can be categorized into three main groups: transition metal oxides<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, polyanionic materials<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, and Prussian analogues<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. Both them have their own advantages in energy density, cost, safety, and cycle life. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="http://et.al" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">et.al</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a>. Polyanionic iron-based phosphates, featuring a three-dimensional (3D) framework, stand out as promising cathode materials for SIBs. Recognized cost-effectiveness, structural resilience, and extended cycling life, they are deemed ideal for enhancing the performance of SIBs. Recently, many of iron-based phosphate cathode materials such as NaFePO<sub>4</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, NaFePO<sub>4</sub>F<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>3</sub>Fe<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>2</sub>FeP<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>4-x</sub>Fe<sub>2+x/2</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(0&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;x&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;4)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a> and Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a> have been reported in SIBs. From them, NFPO cathode material shows a lager theoretical specific capacity (117.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>), high thermal stability temperature (700 ℃) and a suitable working potential (3.0&nbsp;V vs.Na/Na<sup>+</sup>), which was considered to be the most similar cathode material with lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO<sub>4</sub>) for the large-scale energy storage. However, the NFPO cathode material demonstrated limitations in its electronic and ionic conductivity, as well as interface instability. This resulted in a slowing of Na-ion migration kinetics and poor interface stability. There are already many precedents in material synthesis and application<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. Liu et al.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a> synthesized air-stable NFPO/rGO aerogels using sodium alginate (SA) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO). These aerogels demonstrated a reversible capacity of 85 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 10C and retained 88.73&nbsp;% after 100 cycles. Zhang et al.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a> employed AlF<sub>3</sub> as a modification agent to enhance the NFPO interface, effectively mitigating surface oxidation and corrosion. This modification strategy yielded a capacity of 100.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 10C and an impressive retention rate of 96.3&nbsp;% over 400 cycles. We list the relevant works reported in the last five years in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Supporting Information</strong></span></span></a> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>. As shown in that the current rate capability of NFPO is improved mainly via elemental doping method, while simultaneously improving the rate capability and air stability via interface modify method has not been reported yet.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The sodium-rich structure of NFPO easily reacts with oxygen and moisture in the air, leading to surface oxidation and corrosion, forming unfavorable by-products on the material's surface. In contrast, the three-dimensional structure of NTPO exhibits excellent anti-oxidation properties and large ion diffusion channels, making it a highly stable electrode material. In this study, by coating a thin layer of NTPO, the occurrence of side reactions is effectively prevented, resulting in the synthesis of NFPO cathode materials with high air stability. In this work, we construct a heterostructure to accelerate the Na-ion migration rate and effectively avoid oxygen oxidation of NFPO in the air via an in-situ coating method to uniformly coat a high ion conductivity titanium sodium pyrophosphate (NaTiP<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> denoted as NTPO) on its surface. The NFPO@<em>x</em>%NTPO (<em>x</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, denoted as NFPO@0Ti, NFPO@1Ti, NFPO@2Ti, NFPO@3Ti, NFPO@4Ti, NFPO@5Ti, NFPO@7Ti) cathode materials were prepared by spray drying method. Electrochemical characterization shows that the NFPO@4Ti cathode delivers superior performance, with a reversible specific capacity of 108.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1C. Remarkably, even at a high rate of 10C, a substantial capacity retention of 92.66&nbsp;% is sustained under harsh cycling conditions. Furthermore, after exposure to air for 28&nbsp;days and 5000 cycles at 20C, the capacity retention remains at 88.89&nbsp;%. Impressively, it maintains good cycling performance over a wide temperature range. The Na-ion migration kinetics of NFPO@4Ti were characterized using constant current intermittent titration (GITT) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The sodium ion storage mechanism was analyzed with operando X-ray diffraction (XRD), ex-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and ex-situ extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). Utilizing first-principles calculations to determine band structures (DOS), diffusion barriers, and lattice interface adsorption energy. Electrochemical evaluation of the full cell suggests promising prospects for the modified NFPO cathode material in large-scale SIB energy storage. This underscores its potential contribution to addressing the demand for efficient energy storage solutions, positioning it as a candidate for advancing energy storage technology.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials preparation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">The study exclusively employed analytical-grade chemical reagents to maintain the highest standards of purity. The NFPO cathode materials were prepared using the spray-drying method. Initially, Fe(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>·9H<sub>2</sub>O (49.288&nbsp;g, Sinopharm Chemical Reagents) was added to 500&nbsp;mL of deionized water in a stoichiometric ratio and stirred continuously for 30&nbsp;min. Subsequently, oxalic acid (46.138&nbsp;g, Sinopharm Chemical Reagents) was added and stirred for another 30&nbsp;min. Finally, NH<sub>4</sub>H<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub> (23.006&nbsp;g, Sinopharm Chemical Reagents) and CH<sub>3</sub>COONa (12.797&nbsp;g, Sinopharm Chemical Reagents) were added separately and stirred vigorously for 15&nbsp;min to obtain a clarified greenish-yellow solution. During the spray-drying process, the inlet temperature was set to 220 ℃, and the outlet temperature was maintained at 80 ℃. The obtained precursor was pretreated under a nitrogen (N<sub>2</sub>) atmosphere for 3&nbsp;h at 300 ℃, then heated up to 600 ℃ at a heating rate of 2 ℃ min<sup>−1</sup>, and maintained for 10&nbsp;h in a tube furnace to obtain the precursor sample NFPO.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">To synthesize NFPO coated with NTPO (NFPO@<em>x</em>%NTPO, <em>x</em> &nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7), a certain proportion of C<sub>16</sub>H<sub>36</sub>O<sub>4</sub>Ti (0&nbsp;g, 0.0415&nbsp;g, 0.083&nbsp;g, 0.1245&nbsp;g, 0.1661&nbsp;g, 0.2075&nbsp;g, and 0.2906&nbsp;g) and the synthesized NFPO powder (2.782&nbsp;g) were continuously stirred in 30&nbsp;mL of anhydrous ethanol. Simultaneously, NH<sub>4</sub>H<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub> (0&nbsp;g, 0.0115&nbsp;g, 0.023&nbsp;g, 0.0345&nbsp;g, 0.046&nbsp;g, 0.0575&nbsp;g, and 0.0805&nbsp;g), CH<sub>3</sub>COONa (0&nbsp;g, 0.0041&nbsp;g, 0.0082&nbsp;g, 0.0123&nbsp;g, 0.0164&nbsp;g, 0.0205&nbsp;g, and 0.0287&nbsp;g), and glucose (6.948&nbsp;g, Sinopharm Chemical Reagents) were poured into 10&nbsp;mL of deionized water and continuously stirred. After 1&nbsp;h of stirring, the aqueous solution was slowly added to the ethanol mixture. The resulting solution was continuously stirred at 80 ℃ to evaporate the solvent and thoroughly dried in a desiccator at 120 ℃. Subsequently, the dried powder was finely ground, heated to 600 ℃ at a heating rate of 2 ℃ min<sup>−1</sup>, and maintained for 10&nbsp;h to obtain the final target samples.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Materials characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8, Germany) was used to examine the crystallographic information and structural changes of the electrode materials, with data refined using the generalized structural analysis system (GSAS-II) program<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. A scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM 7800F, Japan) and High-Resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM JEM-2100, Japan) investigated the morphological structure. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR, IR Prestige-21, USA) spectroscopy examined vibrational modes of functional groups from 400 to 1400&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, while Raman spectroscopy (LabRam HR 800, USA) assessed the graphitization degree of coated carbon. Conductivity was measured using a four-point probe method (ST2722-SD, China). Thermogravimetric analysis (TG, NETZSCH TG 209 F1, Germany) determined the carbon content. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, USA), X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES, Shanghai Light Source, China), and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS, Shanghai Light Source, China) ascertained element valence states. Density Functional Theory (DFT, Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP), Austria) calculated adsorption energy, energy bands, and energy barriers.</div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035">Electrochemical measurements were conducted at room temperature (25 ℃) for consistency and accurate interpretation. The electrode was prepared using active material (NFPO@0Ti, NFPO@1Ti, NFPO@2Ti, NFPO@3Ti, NFPO@4Ti, NFPO@5Ti, NFPO@7Ti), PVDF binder, and Super P conductive agent in a mass ratio of 90:5:5. These powders were mixed into a slurry with NMP solvent using a high-energy ball mill, mixed for 2&nbsp;h, then coated on 13&nbsp;μm thick aluminum foil and dried at 120 ℃ in a vacuum oven for 24&nbsp;h. The electrode film was pressed at 20&nbsp;MPa and trimmed into 14&nbsp;mm diameter sheets with an average mass loading of 5–6&nbsp;mg cm<sup>−2</sup>. The anode (hard carbon) was prepared using active material (hard carbon), binders (CMC and SBR) in a mass ratio of 6:4, and Super P in a mass ratio of 90:5:5. Glass fiber (Whatman GF/D) was used as a separator, and the electrolyte was 1&nbsp;M NaPF<sub>6</sub> in EC/PC (ethylene carbonate/propylene carbonate/fluoroethylene carbonate with 5&nbsp;vol% FEC additive) for both half and full cells. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were performed using a CHI650D electrochemical workstation. Charging/discharging tests and GITT were conducted using a Wuhan LAND test system (LAND CT2001A).</div></section></section><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0040">The XRD pattern of NFPO@0Ti, NFPO@1Ti, NFPO@2Ti, NFPO@3Ti, NFPO@4Ti, NFPO@5Ti and NFPO@7Ti were presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> <strong>(a)</strong>. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> <strong>(a)</strong>, the diffraction peaks observed in NFPO@0Ti align with those of pure phase NFPO (JCPDS: 083–0225), confirming the structural integrity of the NFPO@0Ti sample, and all these diffraction peaks in NFPO@4Ti, NFPO@5Ti and NFPO@7Ti could be indexed to both pure phase NFPO (JCPDS: 083–0225) and NTPO (JCPDS: 084–1737). Distinct diffraction peaks of NTPO corresponding to the (0&nbsp;1&nbsp;1), (&nbsp;−1&nbsp;1&nbsp;1), (2&nbsp;0&nbsp;0), and (&nbsp;−3&nbsp;2&nbsp;3) crystal planes are discernible at 18.67°, 19.14°, 25.64°, and 49.92°, respectively, in the partial enlarged view. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>(b)</strong> showed the schematic structure of NFPO and NTPO, which exhibited a three-dimensional (3D) open framework<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>. The crystal structure consists of two symmetrically arranged [FeO<sub>6</sub>] ([TiO<sub>6</sub>]) octahedra and two [P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>] units forming a crown unit. Each [P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>] group has two corner-sharing [PO<sub>4</sub>] units, creating a 3D network of [Fe<sub>2</sub>P<sub>4</sub>O<sub>22</sub>]<sub>∞</sub> and [Fe<sub>2</sub>P<sub>4</sub>O<sub>20</sub>]<sub>∞</sub> layers parallel to the <em>b c</em> plane. This network facilitates reversible Na-ion de/intercalation, providing a robust three-dimensional framework for ion transport. The refined X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra of NFPO@0Ti and NFPO@4Ti are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>(c,d)</strong>, respectively, illustrating the structural characteristics of the samples. The refined results indicated NFPO@4Ti material exhibited an orthorhombic (<em>P</em>1) crystal structure, and the lattice parameters were <em>a</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;6.433&nbsp;Å, <em>b</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;9.432&nbsp;Å, <em>c</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;11.120&nbsp;Å, and <em>V</em>=583.6&nbsp;Å<sup>3</sup>. The refinement results showed errors of less than 10&nbsp;% (4.64&nbsp;% for R<sub>wp</sub> and 3.52&nbsp;% for R<sub>p</sub>), indicating the reliability of the refinement. Similarly, the pure phase NFPO@0Ti displayed an orthorhombic (<em>P</em>1) structure (<em>a</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;6.424&nbsp;Å, <em>b</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;9.440&nbsp;Å, <em>c</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;10.981&nbsp;Å, and <em>V</em>=575.2&nbsp;Å<sup>3</sup>). The errors for R<sub>wp</sub> and R<sub>p</sub> were 5.32&nbsp;% and 4.96&nbsp;%, respectively, demonstrating the accuracy of the refinement process. The detailed refined XRD results were shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Tables S (2<strong>,</strong>3)</span></span></a>. The schematic of NTPO coating acting on NFPO electrode material was shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> <strong>(e)</strong>, which indicated that the NTPO was distributed between the NFPO body and carbon layer, which could effectively block the oxidation of oxygen and avoided the exchange of Na-ion with water molecules in the air. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> <strong>(f, g)</strong>, SEM images indicated that the primary particle size of NFPO@4Ti was ranged from 100 to 300&nbsp;nm. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> <strong>(h)</strong> displayed the HR-TEM image of NFPO@4Ti. As shown, NFPO@4Ti had a 2–4&nbsp;nm carbon layer on its surface. This resulted from the melting of citric acid and its attachment to the precursor particles as the temperature increased during synthesis. A distinct NTPO coating layer, approximately 2–3&nbsp;nm thick, was observed within the carbon layer. The lattice spacing of 3.1&nbsp;Å closely matched the (&nbsp;−2&nbsp;1&nbsp;2) crystal plane of NTPO, while the lattice spacing of 2.9&nbsp;Å closely matched the (1––1 2) crystal plane of NFPO. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) image of NFPO@4Ti, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> <strong>(i)</strong>, supported this observation. It revealed multiple lattice planes such as (1&nbsp;3&nbsp;1) and (0&nbsp;2&nbsp;2). Moreover, the EDS mapping of NFPO@4Ti (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> <strong>(j)</strong>) displayed a uniform distribution of elements throughout the material, including Na, Fe, P, O, and Ti. Additionally, the Raman spectra for NFPO@4Ti are presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S1</strong></span></span></a>. The location of peaks indicated that this was corresponded to disordered defective carbon (at 1345&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>) and graphitized carbon (at 1560&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>) for NFPO@4Ti. The fitted I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> NFPO@4Ti was 1.22, which indicated that the carbon-coated layers in all samples possessed a good degree of graphitization. The TG analysis was used to calculate carbon content (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S2</strong></span></span></a>), which indicated that the NFPO@4Ti contained 4.2&nbsp;wt% carbon.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr1.jpg" height="510" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (666KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (666KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (a) XRD patterns of all samples and partial enlargements of some; (b) Crystal structure illustration of NFPO and NTPO; (c) Rietveld-refined profiles of NFPO powder; (d) Rietveld-refined profiles of NFPO@4Ti powder; (e) Schematic of NTPO coating on NFPO electrode material; (f, g) SEM images of NFPO@4Ti; (h) HR-TEM image of NFPO@4Ti; (i) SAED pattern of NFPO@4Ti; (j) TEM image of NFPO@4Ti and TEM-mapping of all elements.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0045"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>(a)</strong> depicts the initial charging and discharging curves for the cathode specimens NFPO@0Ti, NFPO@1Ti, NFPO@2Ti, NFPO@3Ti, NFPO@4Ti, NFPO@5Ti, and NFPO@7Ti. NFPO@4Ti showed the highest initial reversible specific capacity of 108.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> (after deduction of carbon content, the capacity could reach 113 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>), with a corresponding coulombic efficiency of 99&nbsp;% in SIBs. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>(b)</strong> illustrates the rate capabilities of NFPO@0Ti, NFPO@1Ti, NFPO@4Ti, and NFPO@7Ti cathode materials. NFPO@4Ti exhibited reversible specific capacities of 108.4, 104.9, 101.6, 98.4, 95.6, 92.3, 89.1, 84.7, 79.2, and 66.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in SIBs at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 50, and 100C, respectively. For cycle stability tests, the 100th cycles of NFPO@0Ti, NFPO@1Ti, NFPO@4Ti, and NFPO@7Ti cathode materials at 0.1C are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>(c)</strong>, demonstrating reversible specific capacity retention ratios of 99.5&nbsp;%, 99.7&nbsp;%, 99.8&nbsp;%, and 99.8&nbsp;%, respectively. Even at 10C, NFPO@4Ti maintained a reversible specific capacity of 83.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, with a capacity retention of 92.66&nbsp;% after 3,000 cycles, surpassing NFPO@0Ti, which retained only 84.67&nbsp;% of its capacity under similar conditions (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>(d)</strong>). The charge–discharge curves of NFPO@4Ti cathode after exposure to air for different durations are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S3</strong></span></span></a> <strong>(a, b)</strong>. NFPO@4Ti maintained a reversible specific capacity of 108.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> (virtually unchanged) after 28&nbsp;days of exposure to air at 0.1C in SIBs, while NFPO@0Ti showed gradual capacity decay (66.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, decaying to 81.98&nbsp;% of the original) during air exposure after 28&nbsp;days, attributed to reactions with moisture and O2 in the air. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>(e)</strong> illustrates that NFPO@4Ti maintained a reversible capacity of 82.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, with a retention of 88.89&nbsp;%, after 5,000 cycles, significantly higher than NFPO@0Ti (71.12&nbsp;%) at 20C. NFPO@4Ti showed favorable air stability, ensuring reliable long-term performance. Additionally, NFPO@4Ti maintained a capacity retention rate of over 90&nbsp;% during the 300th cycle at 0.2C within the temperature range of −40 to 60 ℃ (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>(f),</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S4</strong></span></span></a> <strong>(a, b)</strong>). NTPO demonstrated promising potential in mitigating the adverse effects of extreme temperatures on phosphate electrode materials, improving battery performance and cyclic stability. GITT was used to determine Na-ion diffusion coefficients of NFPO@4Ti and NFPO@0Ti samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a> <strong>(g, h)</strong>). NFPO@4Ti exhibited higher values ranging from 6.13&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>-11</sup> to 1.99&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>-9</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>−1</sup>, indicating improved kinetics compared with NFPO@0Ti (2&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>-12</sup> to 7.94&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>-10</sup>cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>−1</sup>). This enhancement was further validated by EIS (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S5</strong></span></span></a>). NFPO@4Ti showed smaller semicircles than NFPO@0Ti, indicating smaller charge transfer resistance. The equivalent circuit fitting results showed Rct values of 107&nbsp;Ω, 77&nbsp;Ω, 66&nbsp;Ω, and 115&nbsp;Ω for NFPO@0Ti, NFPO@1Ti, NFPO@4Ti, and NFPO@7Ti, respectively. NFPO@0Ti and NFPO@4Ti conductivity was assessed using the four-probe method (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S6</strong></span></span></a>), showing an increase in electrical conductivity for NFPO@4Ti (1.74&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>-5</sup> S cm<sup>−1</sup>) compared to NFPO@0Ti (1.03&nbsp;×&nbsp;10<sup>-5</sup> S cm<sup>−1</sup>), contributing to its superior electrochemical properties. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>(i)</strong> compares the cycling performance with recently reported NFPO in SIBs, showing NFPO@4Ti exhibiting optimal cycle stability.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr2.jpg" height="573" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (662KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (662KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. (a) Charge-discharge curves for the first cycle at 0.1C for all samples; (b) Rate capacity from 0.1C to 100C for NFPO@0Ti, NFPO@1Ti, NFPO@4Ti, and NFPO@7Ti; (c) Cycling performance for the 100th cycle at 0.1C; (d) Cycling performance for the 3,000th cycle at 10C; (e) Performance of NFPO@0Ti and NFPO@4Ti exposed to air for 28&nbsp;days at 20C for the 5,000th cycle; (f) Capacity of NFPO@4Ti at 0.2C for the 300th cycle at different temperatures; (g) GITT curves of NFPO@0Ti and NFPO@4Ti; and (h) Sodium ion diffusion coefficients of the two samples during charging/discharging. (i) Rate capability and comparison with some NFPO electrodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0050"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>(a)</strong> depicts the predicted structural evolution during Na<sup>+</sup> deintercalation, revealing that approximately 2.44Na<sup>+</sup> ions can be extracted per formula unit at full charging stages. To explore the crystal structure changes of the NFPO@4Ti cathode, operando XRD tests were conducted during the charge/discharge process in SIBs. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>(b)</strong> presents the XRD patterns and charge/discharge curves, segmented into two distinct sections denoted by black and orange colors, representing the initial charge and discharge processes, respectively. During charge process, these diffraction peaks located at 20.4°, 22.4°, 25°, 32.2°, and 34.3° correspond to the (&nbsp;−1&nbsp;1&nbsp;0), (&nbsp;−1&nbsp;0&nbsp;2), (0––1 2), (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;2), and (−1––1 3) lattice planes of the pristine NFPO. During the charge/discharge processes, these diffraction peaks undergone reversible shifts. In order to accurately determine the shift value, the corresponding 2 D contour plots of XRD pattern were shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a> <strong>(c)</strong>. The amplified 2 D contour plots of XRD indicated that the corresponding lattice plane of (1––1 2), (0––2 2) and (−1––1 3) changed obviously. During the initial charge process, the location of lattice planes ((1––1 2), (0––2 2) and (−1––1 3)) shifted to 31.03°, 34.23°, and 35.16°. During the discharge process, these lattice planes ((1––1 2), (0––2 2) and (−1––1 3)) were reversibly shifted back, and the shift value of the corresponding diffraction peak position during the entire charge and discharge process was 0.26°, 0.58° and 0.88°. According to the Bragg Formula, the calculated crystal cell parameters of NFPO@4Ti cathode were shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S7</strong></span></span></a>. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a> <strong>(d)</strong>, the charge/discharge process of the NFPO@4Ti cathode displays reversible expansion with a volume change of 3.97&nbsp;%.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr3.jpg" height="807" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (882KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (882KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) The predicted structural evolution of NFPO@4Ti during Na<sup>+</sup> de/intercalation. (b) <em>Operando</em> XRD pattern of NFPO@4Ti; (c) XRD patterns collected during the second cycle of NFPO@4Ti electrode at 0.1C between 1.5 and 4.0&nbsp;V; (d) The volume changes of NFPO@4Ti cathode during the charge/discharge process in SIBs.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0055">To elucidate the charge compensation mechanism, the electrochemical reaction mechanism of NFPO@4Ti was investigated through in-situ XAFS analysis (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a> <strong>(a-c)</strong>). In the pristine electrode, iron (Fe) mainly exists in the divalent state, as indicated by the Fe-O edge. This characterization provides insights into the redox behavior of NFPO@4Ti during electrochemical cycling, which is essential for understanding its performance in SIBs. During the charge and discharge processes, the Fe K-edge shifts to higher energies and then returns to its original level of 7112&nbsp;eV, indicating a fully reversible redox process for Fe. Fourier-transformed EXAFS analysis in R-space (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>(d)</strong>) reveals structural changes in the NFPO@4Ti electrode at different states of charge (SOC). Wavelet transform patterns (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>(e)</strong>) show that the Fe-O bond shifts during charging (from 0.7&nbsp;Å to 1.45&nbsp;Å) and returns during discharging (from 1.45 to 0.7&nbsp;Å)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>. Additionally, the Fe-O-Na bond weakens during charging and reappears during discharging, indicating reversible changes in the Fe-O bond during Na-ion extraction/insertion. Ex-situ XPS characterization of Fe and Ti valence states during charge/discharge cycles of the NFPO@4Ti cathode in SIBs shows that in the pristine state, Fe 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 binding energies are at 709.6&nbsp;eV and 723.0&nbsp;eV, indicating Fe<sup>2+</sup>. During charging, these energies increase to 710.8&nbsp;eV and 724.4&nbsp;eV, returning to their original positions upon discharging to 1.5&nbsp;V, demonstrating the reversibility of Fe valence changes. This reversible Na-ion storage behavior is attributed to an incomplete solid solution reaction involving Fe<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>3+</sup> transitions. The Ti 2p spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S10</strong></span></span></a>) show binding energies of Ti 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and 2p<sub>1/2</sub> at 454.9&nbsp;eV and 459.8&nbsp;eV in the pristine state, corresponding to Ti<sup>4+</sup>. During charging, these energies increase to 457.5&nbsp;eV and 465.6&nbsp;eV, indicating oxidation to Ti<sup>4+</sup>. This suggests that Ti participates in the redox reaction, contributing additional capacity<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr4.jpg" height="627" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (626KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (626KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a-c) Fe K-edge spectrum changes during the charge/discharge process; (d) Fourier-transformed extended EXAFS in R-space at different states of charge (SOC); (e) Wavelet transform patterns during the charge/discharge process.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060">The DFT calculations were employed to investigate the Na-ion storage mechanism in NFPO@4Ti and NFPO@0Ti. The detailed calculation procedures can be found in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>supplementary information</strong></span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S11</strong></span></span></a>, the methodologies employed for computing the Na-ion adsorption energy, and evaluating the Na-ion adsorption capacity of NFPO, NTPO, and NFPO@NTPO were delineated. The Na-ion adsorption energies were determined as −2.73&nbsp;eV, −2.35&nbsp;eV, and −3.08&nbsp;eV for NFPO, NTPO, and NFPO@NTPO (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a> <strong>(a)</strong>), respectively. Sodium-rich NFPO was sensitive to moisture and O<sub>2</sub>, and sodium detachment made the structure prone to collapse. In contrast, NFPO@NTPO had lower adsorption energy and effectively immobilized Na-ion in NFPO@4Ti. To clarify the beneficial impact of titanium (Ti) coating on the electrochemical properties of NFPO, the nudged elastic band (NEB) method was used to calculate the migration barriers for Na-ions in both materials. The sodium ion migration path, shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(b), was specifically selected for this analysis. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a> <strong>(c, d)</strong>, the density of states (DOS) for both specimens is depicted. The DOS of NFPO@4Ti revealed a projected band gap of approximately 1.8&nbsp;eV, smaller than that of NFPO@0Ti (2.9&nbsp;eV). Moreover, due to Ti coating, the spin electrons on the Fe 3d orbitals in NFPO@4Ti shifted to lower energy levels, suggesting a potential contribution to facilitating the valence-to-conduction band transition in NFPO@4Ti. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a> <strong>(f)</strong>, the calculated peaks for NFPO@0Ti and NFPO@4Ti were 1.68&nbsp;eV and 1.09&nbsp;eV, respectively, indicating Ti coating was advantageous for increasing the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion rate, aligning with the GITT analysis results. NTPO coating method could effectively improve the instability of NFPO in air, inhibit the generation of side reactions, and prevent the side effects of Na. To confirm the air stability, we tested NFPO@4Ti and NFPO@0Ti powder samples exposed to air for 28&nbsp;days using XPS, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S12</strong></span></span></a> <strong>(a, b)</strong>. The peak at 1074.1&nbsp;eV in the Na 1&nbsp;s spectrum originates from the surface-oxidized NaHCO<sub>3</sub> product. The side reaction equation is as follows:<span class="display"><span id="e0005" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span><em>x</em>H<sub>2</sub>O+Na<sub>3.12</sub>Fe<sub>2.44</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;<em>x</em>/2O<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;<em>x</em>CO<sub>2</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>x</em>NaHCO<sub>3</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;Na<sub>3.12-2</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe(Ⅱ)<sub>2.44-2</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe(Ⅲ)<sub>2</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>2</sub></span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr5.jpg" height="420" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (404KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (404KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a) The sodium-ion adsorption energy; (b) Na migration pathways for NFPO@0Ti and NFPO@4Ti; DOS calculation for (c) NFPO@0Ti and (d)NFPO@4Ti and (e) diffusion barriers.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S13</strong></span></span></a> <strong>(a, b)</strong> shows binding energies near 710.8&nbsp;eV and 724.4&nbsp;eV, attributed to Fe<sup>3+</sup>. The Fe<sup>3+</sup> percentages in NFPO@4Ti and NFPO@0Ti were 6.8&nbsp;% and 29.3&nbsp;%, respectively, based on peak area integrals, indicating the NTPO coating effectively inhibits surface oxidation. Electrochemical properties are unstable at extreme temperatures, high temperatures cause severe electrolyte erosion, and low temperatures lead to poorer de-solvation reactions, both resulting in lower specific capacities.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">To evaluate the practical application potential of the NFPO@4Ti cathode material in SIBs, we combined NFPO@4Ti with commercial hard carbon (HC, Kuraray, Japan) to form a full cell. The working principle of the HC||NFPO@4Ti full cell is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>(a)</strong>, where Na-ions can reversibly insert into and extract from the NFPO@4Ti cathode to the HC anode. The detailed negative-to-positive mass ratio (N/P) of 1:3.0 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>(b)</strong>) revealed that the HC anode demonstrated an initial reversible specific capacity of 310 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, with a coulombic efficiency of 90&nbsp;% at 0.1C in SIBs, underscoring its promising electrochemical performance and potential for practical application in energy storage systems. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>(c)</strong> illustrates the performance of the HC||NFPO@4Ti full cell, showing an initial reversible discharge specific capacity of 70.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> (based on the mass of NFPO@4Ti and HC) with an average working potential of 2.9&nbsp;V. The NFPO@4Ti||HC full cell also demonstrates robust cycle stability. The charge/discharge curves of NFPO@4Ti at various temperatures are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>(d)</strong>, with capacities of 50.4, 60.3, 70.3, and 74.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at −40℃, 0℃, 25℃, and 60℃, respectively. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>(e)</strong> compares specific energy/power density with recent reports on sodium-ion full cells, indicating that our HC||NFPO@4Ti full cell demonstrates competitive energy density<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>(f)</strong> shows that after 300 cycles at 0.2C, the capacity retention was 96.14&nbsp;% at 25 ℃, 92.07&nbsp;% at 60 ℃, 93.34&nbsp;% at 0℃, and 89.58&nbsp;% at −40 ℃. The rate performance of NFPO@4Ti at different temperatures is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S14</strong></span></span></a>, highlighting its excellent cycle stability.The NTPO coating effectively addresses the unstable electrochemical performance of NFPO across a wide temperature range. This heterogeneous interface promotes electron transport, enhances ion transport channels, improves interfacial stability, and increases the available capacity and energy density of the battery. This cladding strategy notably enhances battery performance and extends cycle life, showcasing its clear superiority.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr6.jpg" height="384" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (403KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (403KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724018423-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. Electrochemical performance of NFPO@4Ti||HC full cell within 1.5–4&nbsp;V range. (a) Schematic diagram of the full cell; (b) Detailed mass loading and capacity of the HC and NFPO@4Ti; (c) Charge-discharge curves of the full cell for the first two cycles at 0.1C; (d) Energy/power densities were compared with some sodium-ion full batteries; (e) Full cell charge/discharge curves at different temperatures; (f) Cycling performance of NFPO@4Ti||HC full cell at 0.2C.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">A NaTiP<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>-coated off-stoichiometric Na<sub>3.12</sub>Fe<sub>2.44</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>2</sub> was synthesized for SIBs, exhibiting a high reversible specific capacity of 108.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1C, excellent rate capability of 79.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 50C, long cycle life of 5,000 cycles at 20C, and high air stability for 28&nbsp;days. <em>Operando</em> XRD, ex-situ XPS, and ex-situ EXAFS spectra revealed that the NFPO@4Ti cathode operates via a reversible Na-ion storage mechanism based on Fe<sup>2+</sup>/Fe<sup>2+</sup> redox, with a small volume change rate of 3.94&nbsp;%. DFT calculations, GITT, and EIS tests showed that the NTPO coating forms a heterogeneous interface on the NFPO surface, facilitating charge rearrangement, reducing Na-ion precipitation, and minimizing moisture and oxygen effects, thus enhancing air and high-temperature stability. The HC||NFPO@4Ti full cell demonstrated a maximum specific energy density of 203 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup> with an average working potential of 2.9&nbsp;V. High/low-temperature tests confirmed its effectiveness across a wide temperature range, from −40 to 60 ℃, suitable for various environmental conditions. These findings suggest that the developed iron-based SIBs system offers high energy density, excellent rate capability, long cycle life, air stability, and wide operating temperature range, making it a promising candidate for large-scale energy storage applications. The cost-effectiveness of producing NTPO-coated NFPO on an industrial scale still needs to be evaluated and continues to be explored in the future.</div></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080"><strong>Hao Zhang:</strong> Writing – original draft. <strong>Qiubo Li:</strong> Project administration. <strong>Xinyue Xu:</strong> Conceptualization. <strong>Hui Yang:</strong> Conceptualization. <strong>Guodong Li:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Zhaolu Liu:</strong> Investigation. <strong>Mochou Liao:</strong> Validation. <strong>Jie Xu:</strong> Methodology. <strong>Xun-Lu Li:</strong> Resources. <strong>Nan Wang:</strong> Software. <strong>Junxi Zhang:</strong> Funding acquisition. <strong>Haoyang Peng:</strong> Visualization, Supervision. <strong>Yongjie Cao:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">This work was funded by the <span id="gp005">Science and Technology Commission of Shanghai Municipality</span> (Grant No. 19D.Z.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2271100</span></span></a>), and the <span id="gp010">China Postdoctoral Science Foundation</span> (2024&nbsp;<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">M750490</span></span></a>). lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85097667691&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=A%20Low-Temperature%20Sodium-Ion%20Full%20Battery%3A%20Superb%20Kinetics%20and%20Cycling%20Stability&amp;publication_year=2021&amp;author=X.H.%20Rui&amp;author=X.H.%20Zhang&amp;author=S.T.%20Xu&amp;author=H.T.%20Tan&amp;author=Y.%20Jiang&amp;author=L.%20Gan&amp;author=Y.Z.%20Feng&amp;author=C.C.%20Li&amp;author=Y.%20Yu" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0270"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">S. Jena, A. Mitra, S. Das, D. Das, S. Agrawal, K. Das, S.B. Majumder, S. Das</div><div id="ref-id-h0270" class="title text-m">A strategy for designing low-cost, environment-friendly, high energy and power density sodium-ion full cells: Effect of extrinsic pseudocapacitance</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">J. Fang, Y.Y. Zhang, C.X. Miao, K. Zhu, Y. Chen, F. Du, J.L. Yin, K. Ye, K. Cheng, J. Yan, G.L. Wang, D.X. Cao</div><div id="ref-id-h0275" class="title text-m">MXene-Derived Defect-Rich TiO<sub>2</sub>@rGO as High-Rate Anodes for Full Na Ion Batteries and Capacitors</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Nano-Micro Lett., 12 (2020), p. 128, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1007/s40820-020-00471-9" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10.1007/s40820-020-00471-9</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85086505109&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0"
